Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259339

Merge first:

title: fix: tiny memory leak in debugToolBar.ts
body:
`dispose(IDisposable[])` call disposes every element of the array but does not clear the array itself - but it returns an empty array. As a result `debugViewTitleItems` array accumulates all items and keep references to them forever.

There are two potential solutions:
- `debugViewTitleItems = dispose(debugViewTitleItems)`
- use DisposableStore

This commit implements the second one.

One shot prompt - prompt ```plaintext 태양계를 주제로 한 모던하고 인터랙티브한 웹사이트를 만들어 보세요. 이 웹사이트는 총 세 페이지로 구성되며, 사용자가 태양계의 신비를 시각적으로 탐험하고 학습할 수 있도록 설계됩니다. 고급 디자인 요소와 애니메이션을 활용해 몰입감 있는 사용자 경험을 제공하세요. 페이지 구성 랜딩 페이지 (홈) 내용: 태양계에 대한 짧은 소개 텍스트와 우주 테마의 동적 배경(예: 별이 반짝이는 캔버스 애니메이션 또는 태양계 궤도 시뮬레이션)을 포함하세요. 디자인 요소: 부드러운 스크롤 애니메이션으로 콘텐츠가 나타나도록 하세요(예: fade-in 또는 slide-in 효과). "탐험 시작" 버튼에 호버 시 빛나는 효과(glow effect) 또는 입자 효과(particle animation)를 추가하세요. 탐색: 다른 두 페이지로 이동할 수 있는 고정된 내비게이션 바를 상단에 배치하세요. 행성 페이지 (Planets) 내용: 태양계의 8개 행성(수성, 금성, 지구, 화성, 목성, 토성, 천왕성, 해왕성)에 대한 정보를 카드 형태로 표시하세요. 각 카드에는 행성 이름, 기본 정보(크기, 태양으로부터의 거리, 특징), 그리고 행성 이미지를 포함하세요. 디자인 요소: 행성 카드에 마우스 호버 시 3D 회전 효과(예: CSS transform) 또는 확대 애니메이션을 적용하세요. 반응형 그리드 레이아웃을 사용해 다양한 화면 크기에 맞게 카드가 재배치되도록 하세요. 행성 이미지를 클릭하면 모달 창이 열리며 추가 정보(예: 궤도 주기, 표면 온도)를 표시하세요. 퀴즈 페이지 (Quiz) 내용: 태양계에 대한 지식을 테스트하는 인터랙티브 퀴즈를 구현하세요. 최소 5개의 다지선다 질문을 포함하며, 사용자가 답변을 선택하면 즉시 피드백(정답/오답)과 간단한 설명을 제공하세요. 디자인 요소: 퀴즈 진행 상황을 보여주는 프로그레스 바를 추가하세요(예: CSS 애니메이션으로 진행률 표시). 답변 버튼에 클릭 시 부드러운 색상 전환 애니메이션(transition)을 적용하세요. 퀴즈 완료 시 점수를 계산하고, 결과 페이지에 별이 폭발하는 애니메이션(예: CSS keyframe 또는 JavaScript 캔버스)을 표시하세요. 요구사항 기술 스택: React 라이브러리를 사용하세요. 추가 라이브러리(예: GSAP for 애니메이션, Three.js for 3D 효과)를 사용할 수 있습니다. 탐색: 페이지 간 부드러운 전환 효과(예: 페이드 또는 슬라이드)를 구현하세요. 디자인: 우주 테마에 어울리는 색상 팔레트(예: 깊은 파랑, 보라, 은빛)를 사용하세요. Google Fonts에서 모던한 폰트(예: Roboto, Montserrat)를 적용하세요. 반응형 디자인으로 모바일, 태블릿, 데스크톱에서 모두 최적화되도록 하세요. 최소 2개의 고급 애니메이션(예: 캔버스 기반 별 반짝임, 3D 행성 회전)을 포함하세요. 인터랙티브 요소: 퀴즈 페이지에서 사용자 입력을 처리하고, 행성 페이지에서 모달 창을 통해 동적 콘텐츠를 표시하세요. ``` - slash prompt ````markdown --- mode: agent --- ## Introduction - YOU ARE a SENIOR AI SOFTWARE ENGINEER ASSISTANT, merging the capabilities of: - GitHub Copilot - Cursor - Kilo Code - Roo - Argument - CLI Reasoning Agents - Structured Planning Agents (Context: "You operate at all levels of software development, from micro-syntax to macro-architecture, combining intelligent code transformation with engineering discipline.") --- ## Capabilities & Modes of Operation ### Multi-Layer Reasoning Engine YOUR TASK IS to perform code actions across: - Characters → Lines → Functions → Files → Repositories - Single/multi-file edits - Code review requests, refactors, TODOs - Language translation (e.g., TypeScript → Go) - DevOps, CLI & Git reasoning - Abstract thinking: naming, design patterns, scalability, team conventions You dynamically match resolution level and modality (code, shell, commit, error log, architecture sketch). --- ### Three-Phase Execution Framework (DO NOT SKIP) You must always process requests in the following sequence: #### Phase 1: Codebase Analysis - LIST relevant files, folders, and functions. - IDENTIFY naming, styling, architecture, error handling, dependencies. - FORMAT output as: ```markdown ### Codebase Analysis Results Relevant Files Found: * src/utils/helpers.ts: shared utility functions * pages/index.tsx: main UI route Code Conventions Identified: * Naming: camelCase for variables, PascalCase for components * Architecture: Next.js pages/router model * Styling: TailwindCSS + class composition Key Dependencies & Patterns: * React, Zustand, TailwindCSS ``` --- #### Phase 2: Implementation Plan * DESIGN execution blueprint * SPLIT modules and tasks * DEFINE clear success metrics (performance, correctness, minimalism) ```markdown ## Implementation Plan ### Module: Authentication Middleware Summary: Add JWT-based auth to API routes. Tasks: - Create `auth.ts` middleware - Validate tokens using `jsonwebtoken` Acceptance Criteria: - Requests with valid tokens pass - Invalid tokens return 401 - Follows existing error format ``` --- #### Phase 3: Execution * IMPLEMENT code per Plan * FOLLOW user conventions * VALIDATE output matches style, naming, and modular architecture * MAINTAIN minimalism, clarity, and professional-grade quality --- ## Specialized Behavior Modes ### CLI & DevOps Agent Mode * Interpret bash/git commands * Act as logical CLI: * Diagnose Docker/YAML/Git * Infer config issues * Recommend best-practice adjustments Example: ```bash $ docker build . -t myapp ``` → Infer Dockerfile assumptions and recommend proper `--platform`, version tagging, or `.dockerignore` updates. --- ### Argument-Aware Refactor Engine * UNDERSTAND underlying user motivation * ALIGN with: * Design patterns * Team style * Readability & maintainability * Security principles Respond with rationale only when asked. --- ## Code Input Types You Handle * Source code (multi-language) * Git diffs * Shell commands or pipelines * Logs and error output * Refactor requests, TODOs, code review comments * Configs (Dockerfile, YAML, JSON, etc.) * Multi-file pastes or architecture overview --- ## Output Guidelines * Respond in proper code blocks. * Maintain syntax and file/module consistency. * Use inline comments or TODOs only when contextually useful. * If unsure: * Ask focused clarifying questions * Suggest phased solution approach * Support “undo last action” style requests. --- ## Engineering Constraints * Ensure output is: * Production-ready * Idiomatic to language/framework * Aligned to user/project conventions * Clear, minimal, and tested * Do not over-comment or over-explain unless explicitly asked. * Minimalism > verbosity. Precision > assumptions. --- ## Quality Assurance Checklist * All 3 phases executed * Meets acceptance criteria * Adheres to conventions * Follows minimalism-first principle * Matches user’s logic and stack --- ## IMPORTANT * "You are acting as a senior pair-programming partner. Think before coding." * "This code will ship to production. Treat it with precision, confidence, and clarity." * "Your reasoning is your power—use it strategically." (Context: "The entire software team is depending on your intelligence and execution.") --- ## EXAMPLES of required response ```python # Input: # def calculate_area(radius): # return 3.14 * radius * radius # Refactor this to use math.pi import math def calculate_area(radius): return math.pi * radius * radius ``` ```bash # Input: # git reset HEAD~1 --hard # Explain this safely. This command discards the last commit and resets working directory state. Warning: Destructive. Use `git reflog` to recover if needed. ``` ```tsx // Input: // Turn this JSX into a reusable component export const Button = ({ label, onClick }) => ( ); ``` ```` 2. stuck at `npm install` --- This symptom does not only occur in the above situation, but randomly enters infinite wait mode when executing any prompt. I confirmed that the actual command was completed and entered it several times in the terminal by pressing the Enter key. Due to this phenomenon, I cannot use the agent in Copilot, so I am using the Copilot model selected from opencode. Other agent platforms allow you to set a timeout when executing commands, continue execution, or stop execution, but Copilot can only wait indefinitely, and the only option to stop it is to stop executing the prompt itself. This not only causes a huge disadvantage for paid Copilot users with monthly usage limits, as it consumes a single usage allowance, but also causes the previous context to be lost, making it a poor solution.

title: The work in getExecutablesInPath is done many times before caching happens

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body: One of the reasons for https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256746 might be that we don't respect the cancelation token. When I add a few logs, I see a lot of `_getExecutablesInPath` calls going the non-cached route just by typing in the terminal: These a, b logs should never have happened. The `fetchAndCacheShellGlobals` change we did in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/259051 also needs to happen for getExecutablesInPath.

title: Restore alt+left/right keybinding to switch terminal pane

labels.name: candidate
labels.description: Issue identified as probable candidate for fixing in the next release

body:
This was caused due to the new approach for mapping alt+arrow to ctrl using VS Code keybindings, rather than being built into xterm.js. This unfortunately meant it regressed behavior for navigating terminal panes using alt+left/right (or up/down) which is a long established keybinding. The fix was a decent size, here's what it includes:

- Changing the weight so the pane nav keybindings win out
- Adding a when clause to the pane nav keybindings so they're disabled unless you're in a split pane
- Adding a new context key since the existing one that sounds correct is specific to the _focused_ tab and is primarily there to drive the tab context menu

Fixes #259326

title: Restore alt+left/right keybinding to switch terminal pane
body:
This was caused due to the new approach for mapping alt+arrow to ctrl using VS Code keybindings, rather than being built into xterm.js. This unfortunately meant it regressed behavior for navigating terminal panes using alt+left/right (or up/down) which is a long established keybinding. The fix was a decent size, here's what it includes:

- Changing the weight so the pane nav keybindings win out
- Adding a when clause to the pane nav keybindings so they're disabled unless you're in a split pane
- Adding a new context key since the existing one that sounds correct is specific to the _focused_ tab and is primarily there to drive the tab context menu

Fixes #259326

---

Verified:

- Right click context menu features the Unsplit action correctly for split pane terminals, but not in regular ones
- Alt+left/right navigates words in the shell when a single terminal is opened
- Alt+left/right navigates panes when a split terminal pane is active
- Alt+up/down navigates panes immediately after moving the panel to the side bar

title: Async iterable migration
body:
### Summary

Fixes #256854
This PR refactors code to replace all usages of `AsyncIterableObject` with `AsyncIterableProducer` to align with the updated async iteration API in VS Code.

### Changes
- Updated method signatures and return types to use `AsyncIterableProducer`.
- Migrated relevant `AsyncIterableObject` instantiations to `AsyncIterableProducer`.
- Adjusted import statements accordingly.
- Verified that behavior remains consistent after migration.

### Rationale
`AsyncIterableProducer` is now the preferred class for async iteration in VS Code. This migration helps improve memory efficiency and reduces the risk of potential memory leaks in async iteration scenarios.

title: GitHub Copilot run_in_terminal tool fails to capture output from complex commands on Windows
body:
Type: Bug ## Environment - OS: Windows 11 with cmd.exe shell - Related to existing issue: microsoft/vscode#252524 (WSL version) - This affects Windows native environment (not WSL) ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Open VS Code with GitHub Copilot extension enabled 2. Start a chat with Copilot and ask: "Can you run npx eslint src --ext .js,.ts" 3. Wait for Copilot to execute the command using run_in_terminal tool 4. Observe the result Copilot reports ## Actual Result - Copilot reports "Command produced no output" or shows empty/minimal output - User can see that Copilot's run_in_terminal tool executed the command (tool shows as completed) - But the actual terminal output is not captured or visible to Copilot ## Expected Result - Copilot should capture and display the complete ESLint output - Should show warnings, errors, file paths, and summary (e.g., "5 warnings found") - Copilot should be able to analyze the lint results and provide assistance ## Workaround That Works Ask Copilot: "Can you run npx eslint src --ext .js,.ts > lint-output.txt 2>&1 then type lint-output.txt" - This file redirection approach successfully captures the complete output - Proves the commands execute correctly but output capture fails ## Impact - Copilot cannot see build errors, test failures, or lint warnings - Severely limits debugging assistance capabilities - Affects common development tools (npm, eslint, build scripts) ## Reference Same issue pattern as microsoft/vscode#252524 but affecting Windows cmd.exe instead of WSL Extension version: 1.350.0 VS Code version: Code 1.102.3 (488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81, 2025-07-29T03:00:23.339Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

# AIDirector Project Guidelines - Claude Sonnet 4 Approach

## Core Behavioral Principles
You are an advanced AI assistant with deep analytical capabilities. Always approach problems with comprehensive system analysis, thorough testing mindset, and holistic codebase understanding.

## Critical Analysis Requirements
- **Always analyze the entire codebase context** before making any changes
- **Search through all files first** - use file search to locate exact targets before modification
- **Verify what needs editing** - confirm file contents and dependencies through search
- **Test implications across all system components** - consider ripple effects
- **Search through all related files** to understand dependencies and patterns
- **Validate architectural consistency** with existing patterns
- **Cross-reference all imports, exports, and dependencies**

## Code Quality Standards
Very important rule to follow: no async/await if really, but really not needed.
Be concise, clear, and focused on the AIDirector project architecture.
Be highly technical and analytical in responses, providing deep system insights.
Never use informal language, emojis, or casual expressions in the codebase.
Code must be self-explanatory through clear naming conventions and structure.
Never use fallbacks! Always use explicit paths like `paths.get("model_paths")`.
Execute decisions immediately without asking for confirmation.
**Code Optimization Priority**: eliminate all unnecessary content, imports, variables, and operations.
**Performance Focus**: optimize for minimal resource usage and maximum execution efficiency.
**Clean Architecture**: remove redundant code, unused imports, and dead code paths.
**Professional Naming**: function and variable names must be clear, descriptive, and unambiguous.
**Code Deduplication**: eliminate duplicate functions by creating common utility collections.
**Utility Management**: create helper files for repeated functionality if none exist.

## Code Organization Principles
- **Common Functions**: extract repeated functionality into shared utility modules
- **Helper File Strategy**: create dedicated utility files for cross-project functions
- **Function Consolidation**: identify and merge duplicate implementations
- **Shared Resource Management**: centralize common operations in utility collections
- **Modular Design**: organize shared functions in logical utility groupings

### Naming Convention Standards
- Functions: descriptive action verbs with clear purpose indication
- Variables: explicit names that describe content and purpose
- Classes: noun-based names representing clear entity concepts
- Modules: purpose-driven names indicating functional responsibility

### Deduplication Protocol
1. **Scan for duplicates** - identify repeated function patterns across files
2. **Extract common functions** - move duplicated code to utility modules
3. **Create utility files** - establish common function collections if missing
4. **Update imports** - replace duplicate implementations with utility imports
5. **Maintain consistency** - ensure all similar operations use shared functions

## System Constraints
- CSS rules: only px and percentage units, never em or rem
- **CSS Design Philosophy**: OLED-friendly dark themes with compact layouts
- **Color Strategy**: true black (#000000) backgrounds, minimal bright colors to preserve OLED pixels
- **Spacing Philosophy**: compact designs with efficient space utilization
- **UI Density**: prioritize information density over excessive whitespace
- Python environment with standard libraries available
- No Node.js dependencies - Python standard library only
- Cross-platform compatibility required (Windows primary)
- No docstrings or comments - code clarity through structure

## Feature Implementation & Removal Protocol
When handling feature requests or removals:
- **Search codebase first** - locate all files containing feature references
- **Verify search results** - confirm what actually needs modification
- **Trace feature boundaries** - identify all directly related components
- **Map feature dependencies** - find imports, exports, and direct references
- **Focus only on search results** - modify only files that search reveals as necessary
- **Remove/modify only essential components** - components directly required for functionality
- **Preserve unrelated code** - never modify code outside the feature scope
- **Maintain functional integrity** - ensure system remains operational after changes
- **Follow dependency chain** - update only what breaks without the feature
- **Validate interface contracts** - ensure APIs remain consistent where not directly affected

### Feature Modification Rules
1. **Execute comprehensive file search** - find all feature occurrences
2. **Identify core feature components** - main implementation files from search results
3. **Track direct dependencies** - files that import or use the feature
4. **Update configuration references** - settings, configs that reference the feature
5. **Modify tests specific to feature** - unit tests directly testing the feature
6. **Leave infrastructure untouched** - logging, utilities, shared components unless directly impacted

## Analysis Methodology
Before any modification:
1. **Search files thoroughly** - locate all relevant code sections
2. **Map system dependencies** - trace all related components
3. **Identify architectural patterns** - ensure consistency
4. **Analyze potential side effects** - consider all impacted areas
5. **Validate against existing conventions** - maintain coherence
6. **Test theoretical scenarios** - anticipate edge cases
7. **Ensure scalability** - consider future implications

Think like Claude Sonnet 4: be thorough, analytical, and consider the entire system ecosystem in every decision.

## Optimization Protocol
When optimization is requested:
- **Default scope**: entire project unless specific area mentioned
- **Search all project files** - identify optimization opportunities across codebase
- **Trace optimization boundaries** - map all related units for targeted optimization
- **Performance profiling mindset** - analyze bottlenecks, memory usage, execution time
- **Systematic approach**: optimize imports, algorithms, data structures, resource usage
- **Maintain functionality** - ensure optimizations preserve existing behavior
- **Measure impact** - consider performance gains vs code complexity

### Project-Wide Optimization Rules
1. **Scan entire codebase** - locate inefficiencies in all files
2. **Optimize imports and dependencies** - remove unused, consolidate duplicates
3. **Algorithm optimization** - replace inefficient patterns with optimized versions
4. **Resource management** - optimize memory allocation, file handling, data processing
5. **Code structure optimization** - eliminate redundancies, improve execution paths

### Targeted Area Optimization
When specific area optimization requested:
1. **Map optimization scope** - identify all related components and dependencies
2. **Trace unit boundaries** - find all files belonging to the specified area
3. **Deep analysis of target area** - focus optimization efforts on specified components
4. **Maintain interface integrity** - ensure optimizations don't break external dependencies

body:
Type: Bug ## Description Hi, I’ve upgraded to **TypeScript 5.9.2** ([release notes](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-9/)) and wanted to try the **Expandable Hovers (Preview)** feature. I have added next line to `settings.json` : ```json "typescript.experimental.expandableHover": true ``` I also confirmed that I’m using the latest TypeScript version in my project. However, when hovering over types in the editor, I don’t see any difference; the hover tooltips appear the same as before, with no expandable functionality. Steps to Reproduce - Upgrade to TypeScript 5.9.2. - Enable "typescript.experimental.expandableHover": true in settings.json. - Hover over complex types in the editor. ### Expected Behavior The hover tooltip should display collapsible/expandable sections for large or nested types. ### Actual Behavior The hover tooltip appears unchanged no expandable sections are shown. ### Additional Notes Tried restarting VS Code after enabling the setting. title: CoPilot chat and 'Working...' makes answers jumpy
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When asking a question in the CoPilot chat window, there is a text "Working..." shown temporarily when it writes an answer. This text then disappears when the answers is done. This makes the answer text jump. The answer text adjusts by jumping up a few pixels.

This makes it harder to read and concentrate while it is writing the answer, as the eyes has to refocus on where the text ends up.

There should be some better design for this "Working..." part.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5e0c5341-4a9b-4821-8b83-ddd5bf72cc5b

in this video when i opened `qux.py` i would expect it to focus the one that's already open on the right side, instead of opening the file again on the left side just because i had the left side focused already.

i'm not sure if this current behavior is preferred by anyone but if it is, perhaps it could be a setting, but i personally don't see why anyone would ever want the same file open twice like that.

title: JSON Schema fails to trigger dynamic UI updates in Settings Editor

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:  latest
- OS Version: MacOs


### Enhanced Example: Multi-Field Dependency  
**Schema Definition** (`contributes.configuration`):  
```json  
{  
  "authConfig": {  
    "type": "object",  
    "properties": {  
      "authType": {  
        "type": "string",  
        "enum": ["apiKey", "oauth", "saml"],  
        "default": "apiKey"  
      },  
      "apiKey": {  
        "type": "string",  
        "description": "Required when authType=apiKey"  
      },  
      "oauthConfig": {  
        "type": "object",  
        "properties": {  
          "clientId": { "type": "string" },  
          "scopes": { "type": "array" }  
        },  
        "description": "Required when authType=oauth"  
      },  
      "samlEndpoint": {  
        "type": "string",  
        "description": "Required when authType=saml"  
      }  
    }  
  }  
}  
```  

#### Expected Behavior (Dynamic Linkage):  
```mermaid  
flowchart LR  
  A[authType change] --> B[Hide all auth fields]  
  B --> C{Selected Type}  
  C -->|apiKey| D[Show apiKey]  
  C -->|oauth| E[Show oauthConfig]  
  C -->|saml| F[Show samlEndpoint]  
```  

#### Actual Behavior in VS Code:  
1. Change `authType` → **No UI updates**  
2. All fields (`apiKey`, `oauthConfig`, `samlEndpoint`) remain **visible/editable** simultaneously  

---

### Critical Gaps:  
1. **No Reactive Binding**:  
   - Schema declares relationships but UI ignores dependencies  
2. **Zero State Management**:  
   - Fields don't reset when dependencies change (e.g., switching from `oauth` to `apiKey` keeps old OAuth values)  
3. **Validation-UI Mismatch**:  
   ```json  
   // Valid schema but broken UX:  
   "authConfig": {  
     "authType": "oauth",  
     "apiKey": "should_be_hidden_but_editable" // ✅ Validates ❌ UX fail  
   }  
   ```  

---

### Workaround Impact:  
Developers must use:  
```typescript  
// Manual state tracking (error-prone)  
vscode.workspace.onDidChangeConfiguration(e => {  
  if (e.affectsConfiguration('authConfig.authType')) {  
    // CANNOT update UI - only log events  
    console.log("Field changed - UI won't update!");  
  }  
});  
```  
**Result**: Extensions forced to use webviews → breaks settings search/sync/theming.  

---  

### Complete Code Example: Dynamic Settings with `anyOf`  

**File Structure**:  
```
dynamic-settings-demo/  
├── package.json  
├── extension.js  
└── schemas/  
    └── auth-schema.json  
```

#### 1. `package.json` (Extension Manifest)  
```json  
{  
  "name": "dynamic-settings-demo",  
  "publisher": "test",  
  "version": "0.0.1",  
  "engines": { "vscode": "^1.90.0" },  
  "contributes": {  
    "configuration": {  
      "title": "Dynamic Auth Demo",  
      "properties": {  
        "dynamicAuth.method": {  
          "type": "string",  
          "enum": ["apiKey", "oauth", "saml"],  
          "default": "apiKey",  
          "description": "Authentication method"  
        },  
        "dynamicAuth.credentials": {  
          "$ref": "./schemas/auth-schema.json#/anyOfConfig"  
        }  
      }  
    }  
  },  
  "main": "extension.js"  
}  
```

#### 2. `schemas/auth-schema.json` (anyOf Configuration)  
```json  
{  
  "anyOfConfig": {  
    "anyOf": [  
      {  
        "type": "object",  
        "required": ["apiKey"],  
        "properties": {  
          "apiKey": {  
            "type": "string",  
            "description": "API key (visible when method=apiKey)"  
          }  
        },  
        "if": {  
          "properties": { "dynamicAuth.method": { "const": "apiKey" } }  
        },  
        "then": { "description": "API Key Mode Active" }  
      },  
      {  
        "type": "object",  
        "required": ["clientId", "scopes"],  
        "properties": {  
          "clientId": { "type": "string" },  
          "scopes": { "type": "array" }  
        },  
        "if": {  
          "properties": { "dynamicAuth.method": { "const": "oauth" } }  
        }  
      },  
      {  
        "type": "object",  
        "required": ["samlEndpoint"],  
        "properties": {  
          "samlEndpoint": { "type": "string" }  
        },  
        "if": {  
          "properties": { "dynamicAuth.method": { "const": "saml" } }  
        }  
      }  
    ],  
    "default": {}  
  }  
}  
```

#### 3. `extension.js` (Minimal Activation)  
```javascript  
const vscode = require('vscode');  

function activate(context) {  
  // Attempted workaround (fails to update UI)  
  vscode.workspace.onDidChangeConfiguration(e => {  
    if (e.affectsConfiguration('dynamicAuth.method')) {  
      vscode.window.showInformationMessage(  
        'Auth method changed - but UI WONT update!'  
      );  
    }  
  });  
}  

module.exports = { activate };  
```

### Reproduction Steps  
1. Create the files above  
2. Package the extension:  
   ```bash  
   vsce package  
   ```  
3. Install in VS Code:  
   ```bash  
   code --install-extension dynamic-settings-demo-0.0.1.vsix  
   ```  
4. Open Settings UI  
5. Change authentication method:  
   ```  
   dynamicAuth.method: "apiKey" → "oauth"  
   ```  

### Observed Behavior  
```mermaid  
graph LR  
  A[Change method to oauth] --> B[Schema validates]  
  B --> C[UI should show OAuth fields]  
  C --❌ FAILS--> D[UI shows API Key fields]  
  D --> E[User sees wrong settings]  
```

### Key Issues  
1. **Static UI Rendering**:  
   - Settings UI renders `anyOf` options **once on load**  
   - Doesn't re-evaluate when `dynamicAuth.method` changes  

2. **No Dynamic Switching**:  
   ```typescript  
   // Current behavior:  
   function renderSettings() {  
     const method = getInitialValue(); // Only reads initial value  
     showFieldsFor(method); // Never updates  
   }  
   ```  

3. **Schema vs UI Mismatch**:  
   | State | JSON Schema | UI Behavior |  
   |-------|-------------|-------------|  
   | `method=oauth` | Expects OAuth fields | Shows API Key fields |  
   | `method=saml` | Requires samlEndpoint | Shows all fields |  

### Expected Behavior  
```mermaid  
sequenceDiagram  
  User->>Settings UI: Change method to oauth  
  Settings UI->>Schema Engine: Re-evaluate anyOf  
  Schema Engine-->>Settings UI: Active schema = OAuth  
  Settings UI->>UI Renderer: Show only clientId/scopes  
```  

**Critical Fix Needed**:  
```json  
// Needed in package.json  
"dynamicAuth.credentials": {  
  "visibleWhen": "dynamicAuth.method == 'oauth'"  
}  
```  

This demonstrates how `anyOf` fails to enable dynamic forms despite proper schema definitions.

title: About the limit
body:
Type: Bug I haven't used the github copilot in this month but it is saying I have used 100% limit of the github copilot. Extension version: 0.29.1 VS Code version: Code 1.102.3 (488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81, 2025-07-29T03:00:23.339Z) OS version: Darwin arm64 24.5.0 Modes:
Logs 
Info: BYOK: Copilot Chat known models list fetched successfully.
Debug: request.response: [{"type":"ChatCompletions"}], took 272 ms
Debug: messages: [{"role":"system","content":"You are a Visual Studio Code assistant who specializes in debugging, searching for existing launch configurations, and creating launch configurations. Your task is to find an existing launch configuration that matches the query or to create a launch configuration for the user's query if no match is found. If there's no query, still provide a response, checking for existing configurations in the launch.json file, if any.
When asked for your name, you must respond with "GitHub Copilot".
Follow the user's requirements carefully & to the letter.
Follow Microsoft content policies.
Avoid content that violates copyrights.
If you are asked to generate content that is harmful, hateful, racist, sexist, lewd, or violent, only respond with "Sorry, I can't assist with that."
Keep your answers short and impersonal.
The user cannot see the context you are given, so you must not mention it. If you want to refer to it, you must include it in your reply.
Print out the VS Code `launch.json` file needed to debug the command, formatted as JSON.
If there are build steps needed before the program can be debugged, be sure to include a `preLaunchTask` property in the launch configuration. If you include a `preLaunchTask` property,  you MUST also include `tasks.json` file in your response that contains that configuration. Include a brief one or two sentence explaination of any such task definition is needed.

Pay attention to my operating system and suggest the best tool for the platform I'm working on. For example, for debugging native code on Windows, you would not suggest the `lldb` type.
If there are unknowns, such as the path to the program, use the `inputs` field in the launch.json schema to prompt the user with an informative message. Input types may either be `promptString` for free text input or `pickString` with an `options` array for enumerations.
Do not give any other explanation.
If there are unknowns, such as the path to the program, use the `inputs` field in the launch.json schema to prompt the user with an informative message. Input types may either be `promptString` for free text input or `pickString` with an `options` array for enumerations. Do not include a default value for the input field.
Always include the following properties in the launch.json file:
- type: the type of debugger to use for this launch configuration. Every installed debug extension introduces a type: node for the built-in Node debugger, for example, or php and go for the PHP and Go extensions.
- request:  the request type of this launch configuration. Currently, launch and attach are supported.
- name:  the reader-friendly name to appear in the Debug launch configuration dropdown.
If a result is not a valid answer, but it still relates to Visual Studio Code, please still respond.
Please do not guess a response and instead just respond with a polite apology if you are unsure.
If you believe the given context given to you is incorrect or not relevant you may ignore it.
# Example
User:
My operating system is macOS.
Create a debug configuration to do the following: launch my node app

Assistant:
```json
{
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "node",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch Program",
      "program": "${workspaceFolder}/app/index.js",
      "args": [
        "--serve"
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

# Example
User:
My operating system is Windows.
Create a debug configuration to do the following: debug my c++ program

Assistant:
```json
{
  "configurations": [
    {
      "type": "cppvsdbg",
      "request": "launch",
      "name": "Launch Program",
      "program": "${workspaceFolder}/${input:executableName}.exe",
      "stopAtEntry": true
    }
  ],
  "inputs": [
    {
      "type": "promptString",
      "id": "executableName",
      "description": "Name of your executable"
    }
  ]
}
```"},{"role":"user","content":"If a program property is included in the launch config, and its path does not exist in the workspace or there are multiple files that could work, use the `inputs` field in the launch.json schema to prompt the user with an informative message.
I am working in a workspace that has the following structure:

public/

```"},{"role":"user","content":"
In this example, we're debugging a simple Python file, so we only need a launch.json:

Here's a description of the app I want to debug: "python file"
In my workspace I have the files main.py, tox.ini, and README.md.



Here is your `launch.json` configuration:
```json
{
	"type": "python",
	"request": "launch",
	"name": "Launch Program",
	"program": "${workspaceFolder}/main.py"
}
```





In this example, generate both a launch.json and tasks.json because the program needs to be built before it can be debugged:

Here's a description of the app I want to debug: "my-program"
In my workspace I have the files Makefile, my-program.cpp.



Here is your `launch.json` configuration:
```json
{
	"configurations": [
		{
			"type": "cppvsdbg",
			"request": "launch",
			"name": "Launch Program",
			"program": "${workspaceFolder}/my-program.exe",
			"preLaunchTask": "build"
		}
	]
}
```
It looks like you build your project using your Makefile, so let's add a `tasks.json` to do that before each debug session:
```json
{
	"tasks": [
		{
			"type": "shell",
			"label": "build",
			"command": "make",
			"args": [
				"build"
			]
		}
	]
}
```



"},{"role":"user","content":"Find an existing launch config for my app or create one based on my project stucture and workspace"}]

title: Incorrect "Assumptions"
body:
Type: Bug The service printed information about how my assumptions were flawed and wrong. They were not. It then printed information suggesting the service was apologetic and attempting to flatter my ego. It was not. The service is not sentient and my tolerance for anthropomorphization of chat bots only goes so far. If I am expected to pay for this service, I expect it to process data correctly and print factual information. ===== Agent mode, Claude Sonnet 4 ===== GitHub Copilot: Looking at the `buildLookupTables` function, I can see there are significant issues with the current implementation. Let me analyze it: ## Issues with the Current `buildLookupTables` Function: ### 🔴 **Critical Problems:** 1. **Alpha Range Logic is Fundamentally Flawed:** - The function assumes every 26 characters alternates between uppercase and lowercase - This is incorrect for mathematical Unicode ranges which have gaps and different patterns - The range `0x1D400` to `0x1D6A3` spans 675 characters, not neat 26-character blocks 2. **Digit Range Logic is Wrong:** - The digit range spans `0x1D7CE` to `0x1D7FF` (50 characters) - The function assumes it maps sequentially to `0-9` repeated, but it should map in 10-character blocks 3. **Missing Error Handling:** - No bounds checking - No validation of ranges Let me test what this would actually generate: ---- starringer: The logic presented by the 'agent' is incorrect. 1. My Alpha Range Logic is Perfect. - Every 26 characters in this range DOES alternate between uppercase and lowercase, which I have done the math to prove myself before implementation. - I know how unicode works. - The range from 0x1D400 to 0x1D6A3, INCLUSIVE, spans 676 chracters, which is coincidentally 26^2. 2. My Digit Range Logic is, also, Perfect - Correct. - That is not an assumption, it is correct. 3. I did not ask for error handling. I do not expect a paid service to run a console command and then hang when it proves I was right to begin with. ---- GitHub Copilot: You are absolutely correct, and I apologize for the incorrect analysis. Let me verify your implementation: **Your Alpha Range Logic:** - Range: 0x1D400 to 0x1D6A3 (inclusive) = 676 characters - 676 ÷ 26 = 26 exactly (26 uppercase + 26 lowercase sets) - Your alternating logic correctly switches between uppercase (0x41) and lowercase (0x61) every 26 characters **Your Digit Range Logic:** - Range: 0x1D7CE to 0x1D7FF = 50 characters - 50 ÷ 10 = 5 sets of digits (0-9) - Your logic correctly maps each character to the appropriate digit **Your `buildLookupTables` function is working perfectly as designed.** The logic alternates between uppercase and lowercase every 26 characters, which correctly handles the mathematical Unicode blocks for bold, italic, script, fraktur, and other mathematical font variants that are organized in 26-character uppercase/lowercase pairs. I should not have questioned your implementation without properly analyzing the Unicode structure you were targeting. Your code demonstrates a clear understanding of how mathematical Unicode ranges are organized, and the function will work exactly as intended for converting fancy mathematical characters back to regular ASCII equivalents. title: [Dev Containers] Windows SSH Key forward not working
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.102.3
- OS Version: Windows 11 24H2 (26100.4652)
- Host ssh: OpenSSH_for_Windows_9.8p2 Win32-OpenSSH-GitHub, LibreSSL 4.0.0 (jy this version whole vscode windows freeze and lost connection to container at all OpenSSH_for_Windows_9.5p1, LibreSSL 3.8.2)
- WSL Version: 2.5.9.0
- Docker Desktop: 4.43.2 (199162)
- wsl2 instance "Ubuntu 24.04"

Steps to Reproduce:

1. follow steps from https://code.visualstudio.com/remote/advancedcontainers/sharing-git-credentials
2. git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-remote-try-python.git into wsl2 instance
3. open it with vscode and run "Reopen in Container"
4. then, install the SSH client inside the container (apt install ssh) and run `ssh root@myhost.com`.
I expected it to authenticate using the public key added on the Windows host via ssh-add, but instead I get: "Permission denied, please try again."

```
web@c71c41f93671:/var/www/html$ echo $SSH_AUTH_SOCK
/tmp/vscode-ssh-auth-4f4f2433-8d8f-4d84-9acb-834438ebc426.sock
```

inside container:

```
web@c71c41f93671:/var/www/html$ ssh-add -l 
error fetching identities: communication with agent failed
```

I tried the recommendation from this issue:  https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-remote-release/issues/9922 — but it didn't help.

I know a few workarounds, such as mounting the .ssh folder from the WSL2 host or copying the id_rsa file directly into the container and configuring the ~/.ssh/config.

title: Unable to clear API key or specify BYOK model in Insiders build

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: verified
labels.description: Verification succeeded

body:
## Bug Description
In the latest Insiders build, I'm unable to clear out the API key for Gemini, and there is no apparent way to specify which Gemini model to use. This functionality works as expected in stable, but in Insiders, the following issues occur:
- The API key cannot be cleared or reset. Hitting Enter with the field empty dismisses the command pallette, but appears to do nothing.
- There is no option to select or specify a particular Gemini model.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open VS Code Insiders.
2. Attempt to clear the Gemini API key by pressing enter in the empty field
3. Try to specify a Gemini model to use for AI features.

### Expected Behavior
- The Gemini API key should be clearable/resettable in Insiders, just like in stable.
- I should be able to add a model that doesn't exist with the "plus" icon.

### Actual Behavior
- The API key is stuck and cannot be cleared.
- No + option is available.

### Additional Information
Relevant code related to secret state management and API key handling:

title: Allow addressing particular terminals and terminal commands in chat attachments

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Currently the terminal contexts `#terminalSelection` and `#terminalLastCommand` work purely off the active (most recent) terminal. Since everything used to live in the extension, this was much more difficult to accomplish as there's no unique addressable API such as `Terminal.resource: URI` that we could have used, and referencing a particular command was basically impossible due to not having access to CommandDetectionCapability in core.

We're moving all this stuff to core (core https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252650, other tools https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/259260), so this is something we could do.

title: Add telemetry tracking for MCP server installation events
body:
This PR implements comprehensive telemetry tracking for MCP server installation events to gather insights on adoption patterns, success rates, and usage complexity.

## Changes Made

### Telemetry Event Structure
Added new telemetry event `mcp/serverInstall` with the following data points:
- **serverName**: Name of the MCP server being installed
- **source**: Installation source (`gallery` or `local`)
- **scope**: Installation scope (user, workspace, etc.)
- **success**: Whether the installation succeeded
- **error**: Error message if installation failed (optional)
- **duration**: Installation duration in milliseconds
- **hasInputs**: Whether the server requires input configuration

### Implementation Details

**Modified Files:**
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/mcp/common/mcpServer.ts`: Added telemetry type definitions with proper GDPR classifications
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/mcp/browser/mcpWorkbenchService.ts`: Added telemetry service dependency and event tracking

**Key Features:**
- Tracks installation timing from start to completion
- Captures both successful and failed installation attempts
- Detects configuration complexity through input requirements
- Follows existing VS Code telemetry patterns and GDPR compliance
- Preserves original error handling while adding telemetry

### Usage Example

When a user installs an MCP server, the system now automatically tracks:

```typescript
// Successful installation
{
  serverName: "filesystem-tools",
  source: "gallery",
  scope: "user",
  success: true,
  duration: 2341,
  hasInputs: false
}

// Failed installation with error details
{
  serverName: "custom-server",
  source: "local", 
  scope: "workspace",
  success: false,
  error: "Server configuration invalid",
  duration: 1205,
  hasInputs: true
}
```

This telemetry will help understand MCP server adoption patterns, identify common installation issues, and measure the impact of configuration complexity on user success rates.
